body.p:
I enclose you some extracts
from a couple of letters received from my father
some time since but which from press of engagements
and absence from town I have been unable to send
you until now. If you think them of sufficient
interest to publish in the Occident, please do so in
the form sent and no other.

I regret you should have
taken no notice—not even by a line in reply—of
what I wrote you respecting the Occident. Three out
of the four subscribers to whom I ? them have
viz, A Joseph & M Benjamin Quebec & Mrs Nooher
Toronto have written me they receive them in duplicate
I have therefore ceased sending them to those places. From Messrs Nordheimer I have not heard.
Your subscribers in Montreal who now receive from
me are—Mr S. Benjamin, J. A Joseph Miss S. Joseph
etc Brabadi. J. Ments J. Praddiau &ct. D. S. = I
continue to send Piddiau's but he is a member of
the celebrated firm of which Dalphon is a partner
and I don't think he will pay—you had better

send 7 copies here, & direct the Quebec & Toronto
ones yourself. I sent out the extra nos I loaned
my own copy but could not succeed in getting
more subscribers thereby. The few who read have
the Messenger J. Chron & Israelite, and although you
thought the change into a weekly demanded—nearly
all here would have preferred the monthly, because
“the could be more easily bound” an excellent reason.
The fact is Canada is but a poor market for Jewish
publications, even although Montreal is comparatively
very superior to the cities of the United States, for every family
here has one paper. The English prefer the Jewish
Chronicle as a newspaper, the literary value of a
paper is not so much looked at. You have this
consolation—your circulate more than either of
the others. Isaacs without my permission used
to print my name as his agent, but when it
was pointed out to me I was obliged to request
him to withdraw it as although I will do what
I can to advance Jewish publications yet I cannot
have my name published as agent. There are always
those who think the line containing their name
the most interesting reading matter in the paper.
I handed him the name of E. Moss ? in
a conversation with him I told him that
“the? were my sentiments.”

Mr Joseph has handed me a list of those
in arrears for the Occident, and having just returned
home, I will endeavor to collect what I can. A couple
of weeks since before a jaunt to the lakes I have
just taken—I addressed Mrs Naaher as in Mr J's
list she was down for three or four (I believe four)
years. Mr J. I know was most punctual in
giving her numbe to young Solomon who ? with
me to mail. I enclose Mrs J's ably-received
during my absence from home & please let me know
what I am to do. You perceive she subscribes to
the Occident Advertiser. I regularly supply your
Montreal subscribers, and shall be very happy to
continue to do so if you prefer sending them this
way. I pay Canada postage one cent on each
number.

I have nothing of interest to write you hence.
I do not believe the Polish organation here will be
a strong one. It will not I believe interfere much
with us—for the next year not at all, as they
will continue to be members of our Congregation.
There is the usual Hebrew between the Germans
and Poles. How do you get on—how your
Hebrew. I hope prosperously, and so believing
remain yours truly

Is my fathers paper on Reggioto
finished—He inquired.
